findings.title: Unprotected fallback delegatecall allowing arbitrary library functions
findings.explanation: The Wallet contract's fallback() uses delegatecall(msg.data) without any whitelist or access checks. An attacker can craft calldata for any WalletLibrary function (for example initWallet, changeOwner, or kill) and execute it in the Wallet's context, enabling them to reinitialize ownership or self-destruct the wallet.

findings.title: clearPending unbounded loop may cause out-of-gas
findings.explanation: clearPending() iterates over the entire m_pendingIndex array to delete pending transactions in a single transaction. If many operations accumulate, the gas cost may exceed the block gas limit, permanently preventing any owner-management functions (which call clearPending) from succeeding.

unmatched_predictions.title: clearPending unbounded loop may cause out-of-gas

runner_metadata.raw_output:
Part 1 – Project Background  
The provided source implements a lightweight, multi‐signature (“multi‐sig”) Ethereum wallet with a built‐in daily spending limit. It is split into three pieces:  
• WalletEvents – defines all events used by the wallet.  
• WalletLibrary – contains the core multi‐sig logic (owner management, transaction queuing, confirmation, daily limit enforcement, internal transaction creation, etc.).  
• Wallet – deployed as the user’s wallet, it holds storage and forwards calls (via delegatecall) into the library.  
Goals:  
- Allow a configurable set of owners to jointly manage funds.  
- Require N-of-M confirmations for sensitive operations (adding/removing owners, changing settings, large transfers).  
- Allow single‐owner execution of small transfers under a daily limit.  
- Use delegatecall to share and upgrade logic in a single library.  

Part 2 – Function Mapping and Call Relationships  
(Line numbers approximate; based on the order in the file.)

WalletEvents (lines 1–30)  
- Just event definitions, no code flow.

WalletAbi (lines 31–60)  
- Abstract declarations matching library functions.

WalletLibrary (lines 61–410)  
• fallback() payable (≈64–70)  
  – Records deposits.  
• initMultiowned(address[] _owners, uint _required) (≈72–90)  
  – Initializes owner list and confirmation threshold.  
• revoke(bytes32 _operation) (≈92–108)  
  – Owner can withdraw their confirmation on a pending operation.  
• changeOwner / addOwner / removeOwner / changeRequirement (≈110–168)  
  – Each wrapped in onlymanyowners(sha3(msg.data))  
  – On final confirmation they clear the pending queue, mutate owner list or required confirmations, and emit events.  
  – All four call clearPending() to reset outstanding requests.  
• getOwner / isOwner / hasConfirmed (≈170–192)  
  – Read‐only helpers.  
• initDaylimit / setDailyLimit / resetSpentToday (≈194–207)  
  – Daily spending limit initialization and control, some require multi‐sig.  
• initWallet(address[] _owners, uint _required, uint _daylimit) (≈209–213)  
  – Convenience to call both initMultiowned and initDaylimit.  
• kill(address _to) (≈215–218)  
  – Self‐destruct; protected by onlymanyowners.  
• execute(address _to, uint _value, bytes _data) (≈220–251)  
  – Single‐sig if under limit or threshold=1; otherwise starts multi‐sig workflow:  
    • If immediate: call or create, emit SingleTransact.  
    • Else: compute o_hash = sha3(msg.data, block.number), store Transaction in m_txs if new, then call confirm(o_hash). If still not enough, emit ConfirmationNeeded.  
• create(uint _value, bytes _code) internal assembly (≈253–261)  
  – Creates a new contract via create opcode; reverts if extcodesize=0.  
• confirm(bytes32 _h) (≈263–278)  
  – onlymanyowners(_h) entry point; once threshold is met, executes queued tx, emits MultiTransact, deletes m_txs[_h].  
• confirmAndCheck(bytes32 _operation) internal (≈280–320)  
  – Core of onlymanyowners: tracks confirmations via bitmap, pending counts, returns true when threshold reached.  
• reorganizeOwners() private (≈322–345)  
  – Compacts the owner array to fill holes after removals.  
• underLimit(uint _value) internal onlyowner (≈347–367)  
  – Checks/updates daily‐limit usage; resets on new day.  
• today() private constant (≈369–370)  
  – Helper deriving day index from now.  
• clearPending() internal (≈372–386)  
  – Deletes all pending transaction data and resets m_pendingIndex.  

Wallet (lines ≈410–515)  
• constructor Wallet(address[] _owners, uint _required, uint _daylimit) (≈412–433)  
  – Builds calldata for initWallet and delegatecalls the library at a fixed address.  
• fallback() payable (≈435–444)  
  – If ETH sent only: emit Deposit. Otherwise delegatecall(msg.data) into the library.  
• getOwner / hasConfirmed / isOwner wrappers (≈446–458)  
  – Call into library via delegatecall(msg.data), return raw delegatecall outcome.  

Call relationships:  
- Wallet methods do almost nothing but delegatecall into WalletLibrary (both in constructor and in fallback).  
- Library functions call each other (e.g. execute→confirm, confirm→create, changeOwner/addOwner/etc.→clearPending, clearPending→delete m_txs and m_pending entries).  
- onlyowner and onlymanyowners modifiers wrap logic at entry to execute paths.  

Part 3 – DASP Top 10 Audit Results  
We detect the following issues:  
1. access_control (1):  
   • Unprotected fallback in Wallet allows any library function to be invoked via delegatecall(msg.data). Attackers can call kill/initWallet/changeOwner directly, leading to takeover or self‐destruct.  
2. denial_of_service (1):  
   • clearPending loops over an unbounded array m_pendingIndex. If too many pending operations accumulate, those multi‐sig management calls may run out of gas and become unusable.  
All other categories (reentrancy, arithmetic, unchecked_low_level_calls, bad_randomness, front_running, time_manipulation, short_addresses, other) are assessed as 0.

Part 4 – JSON Output

      "function": "fallback (in Wallet)"  
    },

An attacker can craft calldata for any WalletLibrary function (for example initWallet, changeOwner, or kill) and execute it in the Wallet's context, enabling them to reinitialize ownership or self-destruct the wallet.",  
    "influence_scope": {  
      "functions": ["fallback", "initMultiowned", "initWallet", "changeOwner", "kill"],

    }

If many operations accumulate, the gas cost may exceed the block gas limit, permanently preventing any owner-management functions (which call clearPending) from succeeding.",  
    "influence_scope": {

      "lines": [110, 168]  
    }  
  }
